Package gov.nih.nlm.nls.mps

Java representation of the MedPost/SKR Part of Speech Tagger for BioMedical Text.

See:
          Description

Class Summary
Lex Load, access, and search the trained Lexicon data.
MedPostSKRTranslator Translates MedPost tags into SPECIALIST Lexicon tags.
MedPostTranslator Cleans up the MedPost tags.
Ngram Load and access the trained Ngram frequencies.
PennTranslator Translates MedPost tags into Penn Treebank tags.
Predict Predict probabilities for tags.
Sentence Sentence processing.
Tagger Java representation of the MedPost/SKR Part of Speech Tagger for BioMedical Text.
Tags Determine proper tag for each word.
 

Package gov.nih.nlm.nls.mps Description

Java representation of the MedPost/SKR Part of Speech Tagger for BioMedical Text.

The MedPost Tagger was originally developed by Larry Smith, Tom RindFlesch, and W. John Wilbur from the National Center for Biotechnology Information (NCBI) [Smith, Wilbur], and Lister Hill National Center for Biomedical Communications (LHNCBC) [Rindflesch]. MedPost is currently written in a combination of C++ and Perl. The paper is accessible via link in the "Related Documentation" section of this document.

The MedPost/SKR Tagger is a Java-based implementation of the MedPost Tagger specifically formulated for the Semantic Knowledge Representation (SKR) work. MedPost/SKR has modified functionality and produces SPECIALIST lexicon, MedPost, or Penn Treebank tags. The base algorithms are consistent between MedPost and MedPost/SKR.

MedPost is a stochastic part of speech tagger employing a hidden Markov model (HMM) to combine contextual information with lexical information to improve on baseline tagging accurracy. MedPost breaks down the original text into sentences and then tokenizes each sentence before finally tagging the text. A static table of bigrams derived during the initial training phase is used to estimate the transition probabilities. The output probabilities of the HMM are determined for words in the lexicon assuming equal probability for the possible tags. Output probabilities for unknown words are based on word orthography (e.g., uper or lowercase, numerics, etc), and word endings up to 4 letters long. The Viterbi algorithm is used to find the most likely tag sequence in the HMM matching the tokens.

MedPost was trained specifically for tagging biological text by using MEDLINE abstracts as the training corpus.

Arguments: infile outfile [outFormat] [tagFormat]

where outFormat (optional, default is -prolog):
      -upCaret - "word^tag" format
     -prolog - "['word', 'tag']," format
     -prologFull - "['word', 'tag/degreeOfAmbiguity']," format

where tagFormat (optional, default is -Specialist):
     -Specialist - SPECIALIST Lexicon tags
     -Penn - Penn Treebank tags
     -MedPost - Original MedPost tags

Input is any free formatted text. There are three modes of operation:

  1. Standalone - which accepts a input file and output file. In standalone mode, the tagger breaks the text into processing units at blank lines. Multiple "units" can be included in the input file.

  2. Called method - accepts a unit of text to be tagged. The input should be a single unit of text that requires tagging.

  3. Threaded Called method - same as above except this method is thread-safe via synchronized method.

The output from all operation modes is a prolog formatted string where the text and associated tags are included in a list (see example below).

Example:

Input:
     This is a test.

Result:
     [
       ['This', 'det'],
       ['is', 'aux'],
       ['a', 'det'],
       ['test', 'noun'],
       ['.', 'pd']
     ].
     ^THE_END^

Since:
1.0

Package Specification
  • ngramOne - Property specifying full pathname location for Ngram data file.

  • lexFile - Property specifying full pathname location for Lex data file.

Related Documentation
  • MedPost: A Part of Speech Tagger for BioMedical Text. Smith et al. Bioinformatics 2004;0:2271-0.

Version:
3.0, May 3, 2006
Author:
Larry Smith (original MedPost), Jim Mork (MedPost/SKR)
